title: Were the ancient Philistines related to the Minoans of Crete? What language did the Philistines speak? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Philistines of the Old Testament ( -פלשת , i.e. PLŠT-) are almost certainly identical with the “PLŠT” listed in an Egyptian inscription amongst the various peoples who attacked Egypt a little after ca. 1200 B.C. and who had already destroyed, according to that selfsame contemporary Egyptian inscription of Ramses III’s, Arzawa in western Asia Minor, the Hittite empire in central Asia Minor, Cilicia, Cyprus, and Carchemish in inland Syria. (These attackers are conventionally referred to as the Sea Peoples, even if, from memory, it is said of only one of them that it was “of the sea”. For this inscription see, most conveniently, Ancient Near Eastern Texts relating to the Old Testament, 3rd ed., p. 262.) There are additional textual sources for the devastation wrought by these peoples, incl. the so-called Alasiya-Correspondence, viz. three letters back and forth between the King of Cyprus and the King of Ugarit, discussing sea-borne invaders who are carrying out devastating raids in the area; these kings’ overlord, the Hittite King, has requisitioned their ships and sent them to Lycia in southeastern Anatolia for unspecified purposes. There is also another text which mentions the Shikalaeans (= the TKL, another of the “sea-peoples” in Ramses III’s inscription; the “t” should have a bar below it — it’s a “tch”-sound) who “dwell on ships” and who are carrying out raids in the neighbourhood of Cilicia and Phoenicia. These Shikalaeans end up settling around Dor near Mt. Carmel on the Palestinian coast according to a report of Wen-Amun, an Egyptian ambassador sent to those parts ca. 1100. Incidentally, all of the places mentioned in Ramses III’s inscription as having been destroyed ca. 1200 B.C. according to the archaeological record really were destroyed around that time (with the possible exception of Carchemish). Now back to the Philistines. According to various passages in the Old Testament (e.g. Amos, IX 7 or Jer. XLVII 4) the Philistines had dwelt on Crete before they came to Palestine (which the Greeks, in fact, named after them: Παλαιστίνη, “Palaistinê” is a derivation from Παλαιστῖν-οι, “Palaistin-oi” — Παλαιστίν-η is formed, in fact, with a very old suffix, -η, that was no longer productive in the first millennium B.C.; i.e. the name antedates the year 1000 B.C. or so). That the Philistines could have stayed on Crete for a time is certainly possible, if not actually plausible: If you trace the arc of destruction mentioned in the Egyptian inscription backwards from Egypt to Carchemish and Cyprus, to Cilicia and to western Asia Minor, you’re in the Aegean and very close to Crete — where, as a matter of fact, the Mycenaean palace at Knosos was destroyed round about 1200 B.C., along with all those other places. However, the Philistines would have been invaders on Crete, unrelated to the peoples already dwelling there ca. 1200 B.C. Therefore, it is highly unlikely that they had anything to do with the Minoans (or the Myceanaean Greeks who governed the Kingdom of Knosos ca. 1200 B.C.). Be that as it may, one word, and one word only, of the Philistine language has come down to us, and that is the word סְרַנִים, which refers to the rulers of the five Philistine cities. I give the Masoretes’ pointing (Seranim), but note that for proper names their pointing is often as good as arbitrary. First the consonants. The first letter (ס) originally represented a “t”-sound which the Egyptians routinely transcribe with their sign for the “tch”-sound in “match”. Next, geminated (doubled) consonants are not written in Hebrew, so any internal consonant in such a name could be single or double. The ים- at the end is just the plural ending. Now the vowels: Whatever vowel stood after the ס initially is irrecoverable; no matter what it may have been, in this position when the plural ending ים- was added, it would have become a schwa. I.e. as the original vowel any given vowel is as likely as any other. The vowel after the ר , the “r”, for what it’s worth, is given by the Masoretes as an /a/. So, transcribed without the Masoretes’ pointing, the -סרנ gives something like this: a “t”-sound, any vowel you please, an “r” possibly doubled, just maybe an “a”, and then an “n” possibly doubled For obvious reasons scholars have scoured the Mediterranean world looking for something that might fit that description. Scholars have also scoured the Mediterranean world looking for a match for one particular Greek word for a ruler, a word which is transparently a loanword in Greek, namely τύραννος, i.e. “tyrannos” or “tyrant”. The stem is τυρανν- or “tyrann-”. Basically, τυρανν- fits the bill for -סרנ and vice versa. Semantically it’s an exact match as both words in context mean “ruler”. That is all which is known of the Philistines’ language for certain. The only other clue about them is their name itself. In Greek it is a transparent demonym or ethnikon, a name for a people, with an absolutely transparent derivation: it is a place name plus the suffix -ῖνοι, “-inoi”. The place name is, and can only be, the stem Παλαιστ-, “Palaist-”. As fate would have it, there is such a place in Illyria, to the Northwest of Greece. There are a few more things that could be said about the distribution of the suffix -ῖνοι (limited to Illyria and central and southern Italy — with one, and only one exception) as well as an apparent -st- suffix in Illyrian and central Italian place-names, but let it pass. Anyway, if the Philistines really did come from Illyria, that would put them in a perfect position to swoop down on Greece ca. 1200 B.C., stay a while on Crete, and then move on to end up in Palestine.

We don’t know. They have been associated with the “Sea People” but that is uncertain, and we also don’t know who the Sea People were or if the Sea People existed at all. Best guess would be Greek or some language closely related to Greek. This guess is based on their names and their pottery. This means that they might indeed well be from Crete or some other Greek Islands, which would mean that they could have Minoan ancestry. I am not an expert at all, I just have this from the Wikipedia articles about Philistines, Sea People, Bronze Age Collapse, and the Greek Dark Ages.
